Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:EAPSI: Multicomponent Crystals for Applications in Organic Electronics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Organic semiconductors based on a single molecular building block have been extensively used in recent years for optoelectronic applications. However, systems made of two or more different molecules provide additional possibilities to tune the optical and electrical properties, increasing as result the range of applications of organic materials. This project will focus on synthesis of novel multicomponent materials with the abovementioned properties. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Christian Leo Kloc, known for his achievements in the area of crystal growth of organic semiconductors and the technology of organic devices, at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore. This project will make a large positive impact to the current knowledge of obtaining the most efficient semiconducting materials that will be used in future in organic semiconductors industry.

This award is dedicated to the crystal growth, structural and computational studies of the binary charge transfer (CT) organic co-crystals, made of two or more different molecules which act as electron donor and acceptor. Such compounds will become better, more efficient and more tunable organic semiconductors with a broad range of applications in organic electronics. The main goal of this project is to obtain several chemically different co-crystals of good quality. The researcher plans to study the following two-component materials with 7,7,8,8-tetracyanoquinodimethane (TCNQ) and 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-7,7,8,8-tetracyanoquinodimethane (F4TCNQ) as acceptors, and aromatic hydrocarbons like anthracene, tetracene, pentacene, perylene as donors. During proposed research a deep understanding of the complex CT mechanisms will be obtained. This will provide a basis for development of a broad range of compounds for electronic and optoelectronic applications. The rapid growth of the field of organic electronics assures that these findings will prove valuable to the community of scientists engaged in the development of practical organic semiconductors devices.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the National Research Foundation of Singapore.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was dedicated to the synthesis of novel multicomponent charge transfer (CT) organic co-crystals. The scientific interest behind this includes the fact that CT compounds made of two molecules which act as electron donor and acceptor, show physical properties, especially electrical properties, different from the properties of the materials built of individual molecules. Both theoretical and experimental results indicate that organic CT compounds can display n-, p-, or ambipolar charge transport properties which makes them very promising for the different applications in organic electronics.

Two-component materials with 7,7,8,8-tetracyanoquinodimethane (TCNQ) acting as acceptor and aromatic hydrocarbons such as anthracene, tetracene, and perylene acting as donors have been obtained. Before co-crystallization process single crystals of the initial compounds had to be produced. All initial materials in the form of commercially available powder were purified using an open system physical vapor transport (PVT) method in flowing argon gas. Prof. Christian Kloc (PI’s host researcher) made a significant contribution to developing the PVT method that is why conducting the project in the Kloc’s laboratory at Nanyang Technological University (NTU) in Singapore was very valuable and effective. Compared with solution methods, organic single crystals grown from gas phase are widely believed to be much cleaner. Such crystals have better performance in devices because no solvent molecules affect the crystals.

The structure of the tetracene-TCNQ co-crystal was determined by X-ray diffraction study. The obtained co-crystal represents the new polymorph of the tetracene-TCNQ.

The dependence of the crystals’ quality and shape from physical parameters such as temperature, gas flow speed, and tube diameter used in the PVT method has been established. During this project a huge understanding of the complex charge-transport mechanisms have been obtained. Also it was found how the crystal growth method can be improved in order to increase the yield of desired co-crystals.

Project’s findings have already been presented at the School of Materials Science and Engineering at NTU, at the EAPSI closing ceremony, and at the chemistry research seminar at the PI’s home institution – New Mexico Highlands University (NMHU) where majority of the students are from underrepresented minority groups. Presentations at the research conferences and other outreach activities will also take place in the future.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2016
Modified by: Evgheni Jucov
